captions.text: [music]
omichelle15 from Texas asks
What are some things you should not do in Korea.
Well, this is pretty easy.
Like, very easy.
Let's see.  Ahh.  Murder!
Buying Japanese Electronics
Spitting on people's faces.
Kicking kitties.
Stealing babies.
Setting villages on fire.
Criticizing Super Junior.
And the last thing is that you're not supposed to NOT watch our videos.
You can be arrested.  Punishable by death!
Many bumsmacks could happen!
It's very taboo.
I mean, you guise are ok because you're watching,
but what about your friends and family?
Have they subscribed to our videos?
What are you gonna do for them?
I feel like this list could go on forever.
Maybe they mean something more specific?
Yeah.  Let's start with some cultural things.
Ok.  So one of the things that you SHOULD NOT DO IN KOREA
is walk with shoes inside the house.
Our very first day in Korea, we came off of a 14 hour airplane flight,
and six hours of waiting at the airport
We get to our new officetel.  We're with our co-teachers
We're floored!  We're exhausted.
We didn't sleep at all on the plane
But when we came into the house, we walked in with our shoes
And right away they were like WHAT ARE YOU DOING?!?!?!?!?
YOU HAVE TO TAKE YOUR SHOES OFF!
And we're all like AHHHH and back-pedalled
So we learned very quickly that the little foyer
means "take off your shoes immediately"
yeah, and they have the same thing in a lot of restaurants as well
like, if you're sitting on the floor,
you'll see a lot of slippers and shoes,
take off your shoes.  If you wear your shoes
IT IS SUCH A BAD THING TO DO!
Ok, another thing would be sitting in the elderly
or pregnancy seats on the subway
It's not necessarily some huge thing that you're gonna go to jail for
but there aren't really a lot of signs,
there's just a tiny sign,
so a lot of people will just get on the subway and sit down
and if you sit there you might get either
massive stink-eye, or someone might yell at you.
There's like the old guy and old woman police
and they will scold you if you're sitting in that seat
So do not sit there, unless you're dying,
and even if you're dying, think twice.
So while we're talking about subways,
I think we should also talk about busses and subways,
You've gotta be careful about using your loud, foreign voice
Not your teacher voice
If you talk loudly on a bus, especially an intra city bus
that doesn't have a lot of people talking,
people will shush you.
We've been shushed lots of times
Not me, Simon of course.
Well I have the booming MAN VOICE!
Well this is kind of a funny situation,
because if you're on a subway,
you'll see a lot of ajusshis and ajummas talking on their phones
and they're like, four times louder than us,
but because they're older, they have that right
yeah.  No one will say anything
But because we're foreigners and we're young,
and we're loud talking, we will get shushed.
I can't wait till I'm an old guy
so I can be loud and sit wherever I want
and be like "WHUTCHA GONNA DO ABOUT THAT PUNK??"
Ok, there are also a lot of food and drinking customs that you should not do,
but I think that should be reserved for, like, a separate video,
A totally different video.
Let's just talk about something simple about food.
So if you're eating with a bowl of rice
and you've got chopsticks and you don't know where to put them,
Do not stab them into your rice,
You can put them anywhere else in the table,
just do not stick them in the rice,
stick them up your nose,
it'd be better than sticking them in the rice.
Don't do that.  Simon is incorrect about that.
How do you know?
Sticking them up your nose is awful!
I've tried before.  Oh gosh.
Tastes like boogers.
And the last thing we're gonna talk about is hand gestures.
Whenever you call someone over,
never do an underhanded, like this or a finger pulling over,
whenever you want to call someone over you have to
like, doggy paddle them over like this.
No, you don't have to do, like the full shoulder
you don't have to full swim, but you can call them over this way,
and never with your palm facing up.
Your palm always has to face down.
This and this is kind of like reserved for animals and dogs,
so it's really insulting, especially if you're at a restaurant
and you're calling over a little grandma
if you're like "oh, come here" or "over here"
That would be just like, whoa, so rude.
And I don't even know why that's reserved for dogs
because Spudgy does not come over here like this
Like, the only thing that brings Spudgy over is food
WHO WANTS A BONE?  WHO WANTS A BONE?!
And then he comes running.
So, don't dangle bones in front of old ladies if you want them to come over
Now there are so many things we didn't talk about
in terms of traditions and customs, especially in terms of drinking,
But I think that this needs to be a totally separate video,
we just want to prep you guise for like
basic social things that you don't learn about in a book.
And then maybe next time if someone asks about it,
Maybe we can do a video about drinking
and the hand gestures.  DON'T DO THIS!
So that's it for this week's TL;DR
If there's a question you want us to answer for next TLDR
Leave your question in the Google Moderator page
Or you can check the questions already asked,
and you can vote them up, or you can vote them down.
And don't forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs
And don't forget that we're doing these every second week now
And don't forget to put on your pants before you go outside
and don't forget to floss and brush your teeth.
and don't forget to never say anything bad about Super Junior
and don't forget to read a magazine, not a book.
Ohh...that one screwed up big time.
Whoa.  Oh!  We were on such a good roll.  RRRGGHH!
Silence.  WTF happened to the music YO?

title: TL;DR - Five Things You Should Not Do in Korea

comments.text:
Here is a sorta extreme recommendation so take with a grain of salt. If i 
am invited to someone's house. I will literally buy new everything. 

New shoes, shirt, pants everything. Then only wear then for these special 
emergency situations. Trust me it sounds absolutely ridiculous i know. 

However my friends parents literally are begging me. How do you make your 
clothes smell so new lol. Yea i am cheating but whatever it takes is all i 
am saying. :b﻿
comments.author: BlazinNSoul

comments.text:
the first two are just common sense where i live(us). Like why do you need 
to have shoes on in your home and especially in someone elses? and It's 
just common courtesy to give up your seat for the elderly or pregnant women 
blah  blah blah ;)﻿
comments.author: analsweat gel

comments.text:
Many Americans take off their shoes as well. I think it's weird that some 
dont. We put our shoes up on a rack as we come in.

But very few Americans will ask a guest to take off their shoes﻿
comments.author: beriigirl

comments.text:
awesome channel. Keep it up guys!
watched around 6 videos and they're very interesting﻿
comments.author: JUSfr34k

comments.text:
Haha the shoes in the house thing! I'm a Vietnamese-American, and I wasn't 
allowed to go to friends' houses until I was in high school. So when I was 
allowed to visit my white friend's house for the first time, I was so 
confused because they just walked right in the house with their shoes on! I 
looked around for the designated shoe storage, but I saw none. I stood at 
the doorway like a dog whom was hesitant about going inside, and I slowly 
tip-toed onto the hardwood floor. I felt so weird and uncomfortable. When 
my friend and her family all came into the living room, I could not allow 
myself to step on that carpet with those damn shoes! So I would take them 
off and leave them right on the hardwood where it meets the carpet. I did 
that every time I came over, and my friend started noticing it and doing it 
too, so she would leave her shoes next to mine. 

I once saw her mom lay on the couch with her shoes still on. I was 
floored. ﻿
comments.author: Jenny V

comments.text:
Accurate. 100% accurate. 

In every Asian country I guess taking your shoes off is a must. As well as 
speaking loudly in public transportation. Calling someone over with the 
hands up is very rude.﻿
comments.author: BellaHoped 11

comments.text: All of these also apply to Japan :D﻿
comments.author: MastaNinja

comments.text:
its funny but ive never walked into a house, mine or someone else's, with 
my shoes on and I'm from Toronto... i always figured it was an american 
thing -since a lot of my american friends do walk in with shoes on﻿
comments.author: KawaRyuu788

comments.text:
I just noticed in SNSD's "I Got a Boy" video, when Tiffany says "ttara 
hae", she does the "come here" gesture with her palms up. But apparently 
this is considered rude? So can anyone explain why she did this?﻿
comments.author: Lissa Mandell

comments.text:
In the situation of MV, Tiffany doesn't need to be polite. And palm-down 
gesture is not strict custom to Korean. palm-down gesture has no distinct 
reason why Korean hates(maybe it seems like calling dog gesture). You can 
make palm-up gesture when call your friends. That doesn't matter.
But stabbing chopsticks has distinct reason(ritual meaning). So you'd 
better not doing that especially in front of old man and woman.
comments.author: A Mosby

comments.text:
Is putting chopsticks on top of your bowl also bad? So it isn't into the 
rice but lying sideways above the rice, if anyone knows what I mean..﻿
comments.author: SweettieS2

comments.text: Np :3
comments.author: Janeen Sudiacal

comments.text: Aah thank you for responding! ^^
comments.author: SweettieS2

comments.text: Yes it's fine to put them down that way
comments.author: Janeen Sudiacal

comments.text:
interesting the train rules, rice bowl chopstick thing and the waving 
someone to you, same like in japan. ﻿
comments.author: Morten Rolfson

comments.text: 2:00 who else heard "people will shoot you" here for a second? lol﻿
comments.author: Th3Vampir3Knight

comments.text: In Europe we also take our shoes off indoors. :)﻿
comments.author: Sanella B

comments.text:
Can you do a video about the drinking and the hand gestures? I have 2 weeks 
4 days, 5 hours, 27 mins and some change until I come to KOREA I am a 
sponge be my water. LOL ﻿
comments.author: Blake Arashi

comments.text:
Chinesse people also won't allow to stab the chopstick into the rice. I 
used to do it once and my grandma was sooo angry, then I never make it 
twice.
It's also our culture to call someone over with showing our hands like 
that, our palm should be down side, it's kind of respectful calling.﻿
comments.author: Juwita al-Zahra (주위타)

comments.text:
+Esmond Yeo Yeah, I heard about basically the stabbing the chopsticks into 
the rice being a funereal thing. Interesting that Rice is basically part of 
funeral rites in some countries.
comments.author: Jonel Burge

comments.text:
its because that action means you're offering that bowl of food to the 
dead. you'll see them doing that at funerals.
source: im singaporean
comments.author: Esmond Yeo

comments.text:
I sat on those special seats of their subway cuz there was a couple(in late 
30s,early 40s I think) sitting there n I had to sit even just a minute but 
I got up immediately before reaching the next station xD In 
Singapore,'priority seats' doesnt mean much to commuters even if there's a 
heavily pregnant lady standing right infront of that seat,people would just 
pretend didnt see n just "sleep".﻿
comments.author: fizzie311

comments.text:
I feel like I would forget to take off my shoes in the public spaces so 
maybe just barefoot everywhere?﻿
comments.author: Josie B.

comments.text:
The hand gesture thing is also a thing in France. My French teacher has 
warned us many times about this.﻿
comments.author: Sam Zeigler

comments.text: I subscribed (yeah!!!) no kitties will be dying﻿
comments.author: eburel506

comments.text: I'm not allowed to wear shoes in the house either﻿
comments.author: Danimiso x

comments.text:
"oh-mitch-elle-E" lol. 
oh, michelle.﻿
comments.author: Aldwin Villanueva

comments.text:
puting chopsticks in rice is for the dead, yr chopsticks r like joss 
sticks. Its for prayer or prayer to the dead. I think most asian countries 
follow this tradition.﻿
comments.author: Jezlyn Teo

comments.text:
I remember when I used to live in Japan putting your chopsticks in the rice 
was a HUGE no no as well.  Also, they thought foreigners (probably mostly 
americans) were all loud and smelly.  I wonder if most asian countries are 
like this or if it's just Korea and Japan.﻿
comments.author: HapplyFace

comments.text:
Actually, it also applies to Chinese as well, as in the chopsticks thing. 
It's because that by sticking your chopsticks in the rice, it resembles 
incense sticks for prayers. As for the foreigner being odorous thing, some 
Asian individuals are stinkier but this all comes from genetics.
comments.author: D-Walker

comments.text:
Funny thing is, comparatively, westerners are actually smellier than 
Asians. A combination of genetics and diet has resulted in westerners being 
stinkier. This is to the point that, in Asia, they don't have much in the 
way of deodorant. They just don't stink as much!
comments.author: Skystarry75

comments.text: what about sideways-gesturing-to-come? palm not quite up, not quite down﻿
comments.author: Sam Sproul

comments.text: Isn't that ajuma the same picture you used for the Racist Grandma? ﻿
comments.author: Slimy Weasles

comments.text: Ikr lol
comments.author: Bitch, I'm MinJi Kim

comments.text: Lol, racist grandma sure gets around
comments.author: Slimy Weasles

comments.text: Yup! That's the same grandma lol
comments.author: Bitch, I'm MinJi Kim

comments.text:
Could you tell us about how the South Korean's celebrate Christmas? Do they 
send out Xmas cards? Do they only give gifts to family? Do they take their 
kids to see Santa at the mall? Do they go caroling? Do they have 
traditional Xmas songs we may not know in North America? Do they 're-gift' 
presents they don't need or like ...that they've received previously? As 
teachers, did your students give u Xmas gifts?...﻿
comments.author: Debra Lee

comments.text:
Sorry for bad English.
What Benavidez commented is almost right. 
Could you tell us about how the South Korean's celebrate Christmas?
A: to christian(about 20%of population) = meaningful day
    to lovers = day of exchanging gifts
    the others = holiday
Do they send out Xmas cards?
A: no(except for christian).
Do they only give gifts to family?
A: btw lovers, btw parent&kids.
Do they take their kids to see Santa at the mall?
A: Some parents maybe?
Do they go caroling?
A: no. I just searched what 'go caroling' means.
Do they have traditional Xmas songs we may not know in North America?
A: no. Christianity is traditional to America&Europe, not to 
Korea(Buddhism).
Do they 're-gift' presents they don't need or like ...that they've received 
previously? A: no. It doesn't make sense to re-gift. There's no Korean who 
can say "I have already one. Can you re-gift for me?"
comments.author: A Mosby

comments.text:
I'm not an expert, but this is what I've seen. No Christmas cards. No Santa 
at the mall. No caroling. No real different Christmas songs. Maybe 
re-gifting presents, but I don't know. And some students will give you 
presents, but you'll get way more for Teacher's Day, your birthday, or 
White Day/Valentines Day.
comments.author: J.D. Benavidez

comments.text: I STILL want Simon's shirt.﻿
comments.author: imasupastar11

comments.text:
I love your guy's videos! I have recently found a love in east Asian 
Language and I've fount that I wanted to be a translator. I told some of my 
friends and family about my dream to work in Asian and you can say that 
didn't go to well. They would constantly say racist insulting thing to try 
and frighten me away from my decision. So I decided to do some research on 
my own and well there really wasn't much, but what was on the Internet was 
frightening! It wasn't until I found your youtube channel that I began to 
feel better about my decision. Thank you guys for putting up these videos 
they give me a better knowledge and help me realize that it's not as 
dangerous as once perceived. I know just like every other country where I 
will face some difficult and obnoxious people but at least now I know that 
I will find a lot more people willing to make an effort to know me and not 
just to judge me by race. ﻿
comments.author: Amber Powell

comments.text:
Maybe it's a stupid question, but I've heard that you shouldn't blow your 
nose in public in Korea (not even public restrooms) since it's considered 
super rude and disgusting, is that true? =) love your videos!﻿
comments.author: mademoiselleabbey

comments.text:
No one I know wears shoes in their house and I am in Canada, lol. If you 
wear your shoes inside people get pissed off because you track dirt in.﻿
comments.author: Kayla D

comments.text: Where to find simon and martina in person?﻿
comments.author: Marco Paulo

comments.text:
I'm Canadian and I NEVER wore shoes in my house... why do people wear shoes 
inside a house, it's like taking all the crap you step on and bringing into 
a place where you sleep and eat.﻿
comments.author: SleepingGelo

comments.text:
You know, we always took off our shoes in the house to keep the floors 
clean. I'm American & my family isn't of Asian origins. We live in a pretty 
gross clime though - I mean who walks into a house with muddy or snowy 
shoes on? That's ridiculous. . . Actually, most people I know take their 
shoes off in houses. . . ﻿
comments.author: Dillon Dukes

comments.text:
buying japanese electric products ????
seriously? no one care ^^﻿
comments.author: 서동수

comments.text: "Never forget to not say anything bad about super junior" XD﻿
comments.author: Lee HeYi

comments.text: Oh my god. South Korea is Japan.﻿
comments.author: Glitched Link

comments.text: Do you guys have a vine account?﻿
comments.author: Theodosia Goodman

comments.text:
I grew up with having socks or house shoes and I grew up in Europe now I 
just cant wait to take off my shoes and its the first thing that gets 
kicked off when i get home. Shoes are uncomfortable for me so the longer I 
don't have to wear them the better.﻿
comments.author: Raja the mother of the sheeps

comments.text: Haha the underhand gesture and the shoes applies to philippines as well ﻿
comments.author: xoxoprincessxoxo1000

comments.text:
In SWEDEN, EUROpe and middle east you also take off your shoes when you go 
inside a house. You never walk inside someones house or apartment with 
shoes, you take them off. Because it's disrespectful to walk on the floor 
or carpet with dirty shoes﻿
comments.author: bellosh123

comments.text:
Is it an american thing to wear shoes inside your house? Not slippers, 
crocks or shoes you have bought *specifically* to use inside your home, but 
like the shoes you have been walking around all day outside with that are 
dirty....
Must make for a lot of washing and cleaning of the floors. ﻿
comments.author: Mori Ran

comments.text:
+job1181 Yeah, fuck sweat. I'll just smear all these feces bacteria around 
your house, the piss puddle I stepped in, and the ant hill I crushed with 
my shoes. You are fucking daft.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY actually I pumice stone the fuck out of my feet. However even if 
you're a clean person if you've been walking around all day, your feet are 
still going to be gross from sweat and bacteria. Now if I got a hot girl 
living with me then fi e she can walk around bare foot because obviously 
I've gone balls deep. But if I would fuck you, leave your goddamn shoes on.
comments.author: job1181

comments.text:
+job1181 Well, I guess that's the type of feet you have yourself then 
considering you think everyone else has athletes foot.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+MAJE5TYY I rather have your rubber soles on my floors than your dirty 
stinky fungus covered feet on them.
comments.author: job1181

comments.text:
+job1181 Yes, bottoms of peoples feet are better. 2. There are creases in 
shoes and they're made out of porous material.
comments.author: MAJE5TYY

comments.text:
+blatherskitenoir I wish I knew this before it would have been helpful. I'm 
Asian so I don't wear my shoes in the house but when I went to my friend's 
house for the first time I thought all.. please don't think I'm racist 
white Americans keep their shoes on in the house ( I know I was 
stereotyping which is a very bad thing to do. That is the last time I 
believe what I see on TV or in a movie. NOT ALL AMERICANS keep their shoes 
on in the house.) so when I went to visit her I kind of walked in with my 
shoes on and she had to tell me to take my shoes off. I was embarrassed and 
a little confused because well you guys know why.( I forgot how many times 
I apologized probably a lot) . I guess I forgot to notice that there were 
shoes right in front of the stairs and that my friend was taking her shoes 
off before she entered. So yeah! make sure to check for shoes before you 
enter an American house don't just assume like I did I know I will next 
time.
comments.author: Gabby Xyooj

comments.text:
+thihal123 and you think the bottoms of people's feet are any better? At 
least you can scrape your shoes off on the door mat.
comments.author: job1181

comments.text:
+job1181 Think about where shoes tread when outside the home: sidewalks 
where there could be fecal matter, dead organisms, etc. Walking with shoes 
in the house just brings more of that kind of stuff into the living area.
comments.author: thihal123

comments.text:
+thihal123 I promise Americans feel it's a yucky habit for asians to walk 
in their home and immediately take their shoes off. If you don't feel 
comfortable enough to get completely naked, please leave your shoes on.
comments.author: job1181

comments.text: Yes, in fact very common for Americans. It's a yucky habit.
comments.author: thihal123

comments.text:
+rockergirl83 oh my god, that's exactly my stance on the subject and many 
people I know. Unless you're instructed to by guests you're visiting or if 
you know them well enough to know that shoes are to be taken off as you 
enter, I think it's so rude to walk in and take off your shoes, especially 
if the house you're visiting is unfamiliar. At home, my family generally 
take off their shoes and wear slippers, but to take off your shoes in 
someone else's home is like saying "here I am, I'm going to make myself at 
home in another person's house. "
comments.author: prin okonkwo

comments.text:
+Mori Ran I'm Canadian and I've never not taken my shoes off before leaving 
the foyer o.o
comments.author: Soso Li

comments.text:
I know of no one in all America who lays in the bed with shoes on, unless 
they're slippers.  But I still wear shoes in my house, and I grew up that 
way.  And I am a person who was never sick as a kid except with the 
occasional common cold virus.  So, if wearing your shoes in the house was 
so bad, and door mats failed to do their job, shouldn't I have died of some 
dirty bacterial disease a long time ago?
comments.author: rockergirl83

comments.text:
I've always wondered the same thing, and I fell *disgusted* when I see 
American shows where people even lay on their beds with shoes on. Yuck. 
Even if you have door mats, they're not going to get rid of all the germs 
and dirt. I live in Finland, and even farmers and other people living on 
the countryside ALWAYS take off their shoes when entering the house. Your 
home is sacred, and you do not want other people ruining it with their 
dirty shoes.
comments.author: Dynera

comments.text:
Actually, I'd have to say no. At least not for Washington which is where I 
live. All of my friends do not wear our shoes inside our houses. If you are 
living in a dorm then yes only because the floors are disgusting. In my 
dorm room though, I wore slippers and sometimes I'd wear slippers when 
walking around the main living area. So the shoe stereotype isn't all too 
accurate. It all depends on where you live and in American movies they 
don't take off their shoes because the set is dirty and they're always 
moving around (inside and out). Plus, could you imagine the amount of shoes 
that'd be laying around if the whole cast and crew took off their shoes?
comments.author: cococatbug

comments.text:
+Brandon Persaud That's the reason doormats were invented.  They weren't 
just there to greet you with a "welcome" at the door.  Just read job1181's 
comment, he hit it spot on.  It's rude to take your shoes off in someone 
else's house, because no one wants to see or smell your feet, and they're 
not going to buy shitloads of extra slippers in varying sizes in case they 
ever have company.  Just wipe your feet at the freaking door.
comments.author: rockergirl83

comments.text:
I wasn't even aware taking off your shoes in the house was such a 
widespread thing around the world until nearly high school.
My family never took off our shoes to come inside and our floors were never 
dirty? Of course if it happened to be muddy outside we would take our shoes 
off of rinse the soles with some water or something. Normally though we 
just left them on.
comments.author: Lord Vivec

comments.text:
In my small town where I grew up in Wisconsin, U.S.A we would enter the 
house take off our shoes put them aside on a shelf or in a closet depending 
on the home.The only time I took of my shoes before was when I got really 
bad amounts of mud on my shoes. Homes in the U.S. usually have mats at the 
entrance where you wipe off your shoes and take them off. One reason why we 
don't take off our shoes where I lived was because of weather. Snow and 
rain would push us inside or not allow us to take off our shoes outside.
comments.author: Igna Powers

comments.text:
In Texas at least it's rude to take your shoes off when entering someone 
else's house. No one wants to see and/or smell your feet. You wipe your 
shoes off on the door mat if you might have walked through water or mud or 
something. Just like you wouldn't take your clothes off upon entering 
someone house, please consider your shoes as part of your clothing.
comments.author: job1181

comments.text:
Here in Minnesota we take our shoes off at the door as well. It's dirty and 
rude, though I've heard in other states they are more lax. Slippers and 
shoes specifically for inside are fine though.
comments.author: Anna Lunak

comments.text:
So if I sat on the subway with heart issues and nerve conditions that 
require me to sit down most of the day I'd get yelled at? Just because I'm 
not elderly? ._. Definitely don't ever want to ride a subway, wow people 
are rude.﻿
comments.author: Darius Abend

comments.text: the calling gesture is in china﻿
comments.author: SuperGamerinator

comments.text: that color isnt good on simon. makes him look washed out and pasty faced.﻿
comments.author: disarchitected

comments.text:
This applies to any Asian home in their country or elsewhere. In the US we 
still practice this custom. We do not really follow taking off shoes but it 
really does keep the floors clean by removing them.﻿
comments.author: yokeimon

comments.text:
YES!!! As a korean in America, this is so relatable. My parents will always 
get annoyed if I bring a friend home and they don't take off their shoes, 
so I have to tell my friends beforehand to take their shoes off.
comments.author: T

comments.text:
I mean, we do, though. Most Americans (or at least those who live around 
me) don't wear shoes inside houses.
comments.author: Sidney Jones

comments.text:
i live in Canada and I this is my first time hearing of Americans not 
taking off their shoes when they enter a building i really dont understand 
that
comments.author: Brandon Persaud

comments.text: +Sunny Jones me too
comments.author: owen2760

comments.text:
I'm not even Asian and my entire family takes off their shoes in the house. 
I do that at all my friends' houses, too. I've actually only met a few 
people who wore shoes in the house and I was shocked! :o
comments.author: Sidney Jones

comments.text: I always wondered why you must take off your shoes indoors.﻿
comments.author: shelaya white

comments.text:
I always wondered when you take off your shoes indoors. only time to go to 
bed?
comments.author: A Mosby

comments.text: It's to keep the floor from being damaged or dirty hoped that helped
comments.author: Van Nguyen

comments.text: Definitely calling people with palm-up if I go to Korea.﻿
comments.author: Vakama16

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Irene Braginski
What part of the Southern United States do yo live in? I live in Texas and 
have never heard of this.
comments.author: belita ross

comments.text:
+Irene Braginski I think it's moreso of a regional thing in the United 
States; I live in Southern California and it's also pretty disrespectful to 
wear shoes inside of someone's home without permission, but if you drive 20 
minutes up then you'll find that generally everyone wears shoes in the 
house. I personally think it makes more sense to take shoes off..but I also 
live in a dominantly Korean community so that might be a contribution.
comments.author: Ari Mew

comments.text:
I live in the southern part of United States and it is considered 
disrespectful if you wear shoes inside another person's home without asking 
permission. Also, we consider it unhygienic if you wear outside shoes 
inside your own home unless you are having a house party of some sort.We 
Americans also find it dirty and gross seeing the actors walk around as 
such. :/
comments.author: Irene Braginski

comments.text:
Americans in movies are a LOT worse than Americans in real life with the 
shoes thing. As an American I'd say from my experience that a little over 
50% of American households are shoeless while a little under 50% are okay 
to wear your shoes in. It's certainly not all Americans that wear shoes in 
their house, TV definitely isn't accurate in this regard. I've even seen 
people on American TV sleeping with their shoes on...it's a pretty bad 
representation.

So yeah, the media will never give you an accurate representation of a 
country or race of people. If I believed everything I saw on TV to be an 
accurate representation of Europe I'd have a really narrow view of such a 
large part of the world.
comments.author: thequeenundisputed
